description: Literally, “native to the soil”; from autochthon +‎ -ous.

entries.meaning: Native to the place where found; indigenous.
(biology, medicine) Originating where found; found where it originates.
examples: When, in 1858, Joseph Lister amputated the right leg of a six-year-old girl suffering from gangrene, he noted that the autochthonous blood clot extended down the anterior tibial artery as far as the commencement of the gangrene.

entries.meaning: (geology) Buried in place, especially of a fossil preserved in its life position without disturbance or disarticulation.
examples: Death and burial may be simultaneous, resulting in a preserved snapshot of an autochthonous assemblage that may be compared directly with present day ecosystems.
